conclusion: Need to find the mass of block B given that block A is stationary on a slope with a pulley system.
Smooth slope with 30-degree inclination, block A on slope, connected via light rope through two pulleys, rope fixed to ceiling, block B hanging.
Block A on 30-degree slope, rope over pulley at top, another pulley with 90-degree turn, block B hanging.
Slope is smooth, no friction, light rope, no friction in pulleys, block A mass is m.
Draw free-body diagrams for both blocks to understand forces.
For block A: weight is mg downward, tension T opposes weight, component parallel to slope is mg sin(30°), T = mg sin(30°).
For block B: weight is m_b g downward, tension T upward, T = m_b g.
From block A, T = mg sin(30°), so m_b g = mg sin(30°), m_b = m sin(30°).
Consider complexity of pulley system, tension might not be m_b g.
Re-evaluate forces for block B with 90-degree turn in rope.
If pulley is fixed, tension same throughout, T = m_b g.
Reconfirm m_b = m / 2, consider mechanical advantage.
Visualize setup again, fixed pulley at top, movable pulley for block B.
Tension same throughout, forces balance, T = mg sin(30°) = m_b g.
Reconfirm m_b = m / 2, consider angle effects.
